title: Suggestions for a serif typeface to pair with DIN 1451?
content: I need a serif typeface to pair with DIN 1451 for extended text... any suggestions?
author: nesen

comments.content: Tell us more about the project. Then we can be more helpful with recommendations.

A few top-of-mind options would be:

Warnock  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/warnock\_pro\_regular/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215061041/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/warnock_pro_regular/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/warnock\_pro\_regular/")

Utopia  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative\_alliance/utopia/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215061041/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative_alliance/utopia/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/creative\_alliance/utopia/")

Alinea  
 [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/presence\_typo/alinea\_serif/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150215061041/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/presence_typo/alinea_serif/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/presence\_typo/alinea\_serif/")

I was recently looking for something similar; a serif typeface to match DIN Engschrift logo text as part of an identity package. I've been playing with Prensa, but I haven't completely settled on it. It offers an interesting pairing and it's an extremely well constructed, but it, like Caecilia that Mr. Coles suggested, is perhaps bit too jaunty for my use.

Thanks for the feedback! I'm also working on an identity project. I've been trying to decide between Utopia and Scala, but am leaning towards Scala. I like Prensa as well, but maybe Scala is a little more serious.
